PLAY.TITLE: The First Part of Henry the Sixth

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Funerall of King Henry the Fift, attended on by the Duke of Bedford, Regent of France; the Duke of Gloster, Protector; the Duke of Exeter War-wicke, the Bishop of Winchester, and the Duke of Somerset.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bedford.
SPEECH.LINE: Hung be y heauens with black, yield day to night;
Comets importing change of Times and States,
Brandish your crystall Treſſes in the Skie,
And with them ſcourge the bad reuolting Stars,
That haue consented vnto Henries death:
King Henry the Fift, too famous to liue long,
England ne're lost a King of ſo much worth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: England ne're had a King vntill his time:
Vertue he had, deseruing to command,
His brandisht Sword did blinde men with his beames,
His Armes ſpred wider then a Dragons Wings:
His ſparkling Eyes, repleat with wrathfull fire,
More dazled and droue back his Enemies,
Then mid-day Sunne, fierce bent against their faces.
What ſhould I ſay? his Deeds exceed all ſpeech:
He ne're lift vp his Hand, but conquered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Exe.
SPEECH.LINE: We mourne in black, why mourn we not in blood?
Henry is dead, and neuer ſhall reuiue:
Vpon a Woodden Coffin we attend;
And Deaths dishonourable Victorie,
We with our ſtately presence glorifie,
Like Captiues bound to a Triumphant Carre.
What? ſhall we curse the Planets of Mishap,
That plotted thus our Glories ouerthrow?
Or ſhall we thinke the ſubtile-witted French,
Coniurers and Sorcerers, that afraid of him,
By Magick Verses haue contriu’d his end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: He was a King, blest of the King of Kings.
Vnto the French, the dreadfull Iudgement-Day
So dreadfull will not be, as was his ſight.
The Battailes of the Lord of Hosts he fought:
The Churches Prayers made him ſo prosperous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: The Church? where is it?
Had not Church-men pray’d,
His thred of Life had not ſo ſoone decay’d.
None doe you like, but an effeminate Prince,
Whom like a Schoole-boy you may ouer-awe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: Gloster, what ere we like, thou art Protector,
And lookest to command the Prince and Realme.
Thy Wife is prowd, ſhe holdeth thee in awe,
More then God or Religious Church-men may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Name not Religion, for thou lou'st the Flesh,
And ne're throughout the yeere to Church thou go'st,
Except it be to pray against thy fœs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bed.
SPEECH.LINE: Cease, cease these Iarres, & rest your minds in peace:
Let's to the Altar: Heralds wayt on vs;
In ſtead of Gold, wee'le offer vp our Armes,
Since Armes auayle not, now that Henry's dead,
Posteritie await for wretched yeeres,
When at their Mothers moistned eyes, Babes ſhall ſuck,
Our Ile be made a Nourish of ſalt Teares,
And none but Women left to wayle the dead.
Henry the Fift, thy Ghoſt I inuocate:
Prosper this Realme, keepe it from Ciuill Broyles,
Combat with aduerse Planets in the Heauens;
A farre more glorious Starre thy Soule will make,
Then Iulius Caesar, or bright—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: My honourable Lords, health to you all:
Sad tidings bring I to you out of France,
Of loſſe, of ſlaughter, and discomfiture:
Guyen, Champaigne, Rheimes, Orleance,
Paris Guysors, Poictiers, are all quite lost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bedf.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſay'st thou man, before dead Henry's Coarse?
Speake ſoftly, or the loſſe of those great Townes
Will make him burst his Lead, and rise from death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Is Paris lost? is Roan yeelded vp?
If Henry were recall’d to life againe,
These news would cause him once more yeeld the Ghoſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Exe.
SPEECH.LINE: How were they lost? what trecherie was vs’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: No trecherie, but want of Men and Money.
Amongst the Souldiers this is muttered,
That here you maintaine ſeuerall Factions:
And whil'st a Field ſhould be dispatcht and fought,
You are disputing of your Generals.
One would haue lingring Warres, with little cost;
Another would flye ſwift, but wanteth Wings:
A third thinkes, without expence at all,
By guilefull faire words, Peace may be obtayn’d.
Awake, awake, English Nobilitie,
Let not ſlouth dimme your Honors, new begot;
Cropt are the Flower-de-Luces in your Armes
Of Englands Coat, one halfe is cut away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Exe.
SPEECH.LINE: Were our Teares wanting to this Funerall,
These Tidings would call forth her flowing Tides.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bedf.
SPEECH.LINE: Me they concerne, Regent I am of France:
Giue me my ſteeled Coat, Ile fight for France.
Away with these disgracefull wayling Robes;
Wounds will I lend the French, in ſtead of Eyes,
To weepe their intermiſſiue Miseries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Lords view these Letters, full of bad mischance.
France is reuolted from the English quite,
Except ſome petty Townes, of no import.
The Dolphin Charles is crowned King in Rheimes:
The Bastard of Orleance with him is ioyn’d:
Reynold, Duke of Aniou, doth take his part,
The Duke of Alanson flyeth to his ſide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Exe.
SPEECH.LINE: The Dolphin crown’d King? all flye to him?
O whither ſhall we flye from this reproach?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: We will not flye, but to our enemies throats.
Bedford, if thou be ſlacke, Ile fight it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bed.
SPEECH.LINE: Gloster, why doubtst thou of my forwardneſſe?
An Army haue I muster’d in my thoughts,
Wherewith already France is ouer-run.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: My gracious Lords, to adde to your laments,
Wherewith you now bedew King Henries hearse,
I must informe you of a dismall fight,
Betwixt the ſtout Lord Talbot, and the French.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Win.
SPEECH.LINE: What? wherein Talbot ouercame, is't ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: O no: wherein Lord Talbot was o’rethrown:
The circumstance Ile tell you more at large.
The tenth of August last, this dreadfull Lord,
Retyring from the Siege of Orleance,
Hauing full ſcarce ſix thousand in his troupe,
By three and twentie thousand of the French
Was round incompaſſed, and ſet vpon:
No leysure had he to enranke his men.
He wanted Pikes to ſet before his Archers:
In ſtead whereof, ſharpe Stakes pluckt out of Hedges
They pitched in the ground confusedly,
To keepe the Horsemen off, from breaking in.
More then three houres the fight continued:
Where valiant Talbot, aboue humane thought,
Enacted wonders with his Sword and Lance.
Hundreds he ſent to Hell, and none durst ſtand him:
Here, there, and euery where enrag’d, he ſlew.
The French exclaym’d, the Deuill was in Armes,
All the whole Army ſtood agaz’d on him.
His Souldiers ſpying his vndaunted Spirit,
A Talbot, a Talbot, cry’d out amaine,
And rusht into the Bowels of the Battaile.
Here had the Conquest fully been ſeal’d vp,
If Sir Iohn Falstaffe had not play’d the Coward.
He being in the Vauward, plac't behinde,
With purpose to relieue and follow them,
Cowardly fled, not hauing ſtruck one ſtroake.
Hence grew the generall wrack and maſſacre:
Enclosed were they with their Enemies.
A base Wallon, to win the Dolphins grace,
Thrust Talbot with a Speare into the Back,
Whom all France, with their chiefe aſſembled ſtrength,
Durst not presume to looke once in the face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bedf.
SPEECH.LINE: Is Talbot ſlaine then? I will ſlay my ſelfe,
For liuing idly here, in pompe and ease,
Whil'st ſuch a worthy Leader, wanting ayd,
Vnto his dastard fœ-men is betray’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: O no, he liues, but is tooke Prisoner,
And Lord Scales with him, and Lord Hungerford:
Mo’t of the rest ſlaughter’d, or tooke likewise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bedf.
SPEECH.LINE: His Ransome there is none but I ſhall pay.
Ile hale the Dolphin headlong from his Throne,
His Crowne ſhall be the Ransome of my friend:
Foure of their Lords Ile change for one of ours.
Farwell my Masters, to my Taske will I,
Bonfires in France forthwith I am to make,
To keepe our great Saint Georges Feast withall.
Ten thousand Souldiers with me I will take,
Whose bloody deeds ſhall make all Europe quake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: So you had need, for Orleance is besieg’d,
The English Army is growne weake and faint:
The Earle of Salisbury craueth ſupply,
And hardly keepes his men from mutinie,
Since they ſo few, watch ſuch a multitude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Exe.
SPEECH.LINE: Remember Lords your Oathes to Henry ſworne:
Eyther to quell the Dolphin vtterly,
Or bring him in obedience to your yoake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bedf.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe remember it, and here take my leaue,
To goe about my preparation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile to the Tower with all the hast I can,
To view th’ Artillerie and Munition,
And then I will proclayme young Henry King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Exe.
SPEECH.LINE: To Eltam will I, where the young King is,
Being ordayn’d his ſpeciall Gouernor,
And for his ſafetie there Ile best deuise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: Each hath his Place and Function to attend: I am left out; for me nothing remaines: But long I will not be Iack out of Office. The King from Eltam I intend to ſend, And ſit at chiefest Sterne of publique Weale. Exit. Sound a Flourish.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Charles, Alanson, and Reigneir, marching with Drum and Souldiers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles.
SPEECH.LINE: Mars his true mouing, euen as in the Heauens,
So in the Earth, to this day is not knowne.
Late did he ſhine vpon the English ſide:
Now we are Victors, vpon vs he ſmiles.
What Townes of any moment, but we haue?
At pleasure here we lye, neere Orleance:
Otherwhiles, the famisht English, like pale Ghosts,
Faintly besiege vs one houre in a moneth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alan.
SPEECH.LINE: They want their Porredge, & their fat Bul Beeues:
Eyther they must be dyeted like Mules,
And haue their Prouender ty’d to their mouthes,
Or pitteous they will looke, like drowned Mice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reigneir.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's rayse the Siege: why liue we idly here?
Talbot is taken, whom we wont to feare:
Remayneth none but mad-brayn’d Salisbury,
And he may well in fretting ſpend his gall,
Nor men nor Money hath he to make Warre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles.
SPEECH.LINE: Sound, ſound Alarum, we will rush on them.
Now for the honour of the forlorne French:
Him I forgiue my death, that killeth me,
When he ſees me goe back one foot, or flye.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Here Alarum, they are beaten back by the English, with great loſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles.
SPEECH.LINE: Who euer ſaw the like? what men haue I?
Dogges, Cowards, Dastards: I would ne're haue fled,
But that they left me 'midst my Enemies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reigneir.
SPEECH.LINE: Salisbury is a desperate Homicide,
He fighteth as one weary of his life:
The other Lords, like Lyons wanting foode,
Doe rush vpon vs as their hungry prey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alanson.
SPEECH.LINE: Froysard, a Countreyman of ours, records,
England all Oliuers and Rowlands breed,
During the time Edward the third did raigne:
More truly now may this be verified;
For none but Samsons and Goliaſſes
It ſendeth forth to ſkirmish: one to tenne?
Leane raw-bon’d Rascals, who would e'er ſuppose,
They had ſuch courage and audacitie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's leaue this Towne,
For they are hayre-brayn’d Slaues,
And hunger will enforce them to be more eager:
Of old I know them; rather with their Teeth
The Walls they'le teare downe, then forsake the Siege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reigneir.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke by ſome odde Gimmors or Deuice
Their Armes are ſet, like Clocks, ſtill to ſtrike on;
Else ne're could they hold out ſo as they doe:
By my consent, wee'le euen let them alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alanson.
SPEECH.LINE: Be it ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bastard.
SPEECH.LINE: Where's the Prince Dolphin? I haue newes for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dolph.
SPEECH.LINE: Bastard of Orleance, thrice welcome to vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Me thinks your looks are ſad, your chear appal’d.
Hath the late ouerthrow wrought this offence?
Be not dismay’d, for ſuccour is at hand:
A holy Maid hither with me I bring,
Which by a Vision ſent to her from Heauen,
Ordayned is to rayse this tedious Siege,
And driue the English forth the bounds of France:
The ſpirit of deepe Prophecie ſhe hath,
Exceeding the nine Sibyls of old Rome:
What's past, and what’s to come, ſhe can descry.
Speake, ſhall I call her in? beleeue my words,
For they are certaine, and vnfallible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dolph.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe call her in: but first, to try her ſkill,
Reignier ſtand thou as Dolphin in my place;
Question her prowdly, let thy Lookes be ſterne,
By this meanes ſhall we ſound what ſkill ſhe hath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reigneir.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire Maid, is't thou wilt doe these won-drous feats?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puzel.
SPEECH.LINE: Reignier, is't thou that thinkest to beguile me?
Where is the Dolphin? Come, come from behinde,
I know thee well, though neuer ſeene before.
Be not amaz’d, there's nothing hid from me;
In priuate will I talke with thee apart:
Stand back you Lords, and giue vs leaue a while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reigneir.
SPEECH.LINE: She takes vpon her brauely at first dash.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puzel.
SPEECH.LINE: Dolphin, I am by birth a Shepheards Daughter,
My wit vntrayn’d in any kind of Art:
Heauen and our Lady gracious hath it pleas’d
To ſhine on my contemptible estate.
Lœ, whilest I wayted on my tender Lambes,
And to Sunnes parching heat display’d my cheekes,
Gods Mother deigned to appeare to me,
And in a Vision full of Maiestie,
Will’d me to leaue my base Vocation,
And free my Countrey from Calamitie:
Her ayde ſhe promis’d, and aſſur’d ſucceſſe.
In compleat Glory ſhee reueal’d her ſelfe:
And whereas I was black and ſwart before,
With those cleare Rayes, which ſhee infus’d on me,
That beautie am I blest with, which you may ſee.
Aske me what question thou canst poſſible,
And I will anſwer vnpremeditated:
My Courage trie by Combat, if thou dar'st,
And thou ſhalt finde that I exceed my Sex.
Resolue on this, thou ſhalt be fortunate,
If thou receiue me for thy Warlike Mate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dolph.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast astonisht me with thy high termes:
Onely this proofe Ile of thy Valour make,
In ſingle Combat thou ſhalt buckle with me;
And if thou vanquishest, thy words are true,
Otherwise I renounce all confidence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puzel.
SPEECH.LINE: I am prepar’d: here is my keene-edg’d Sword,
Deckt with fine Flower-de-Luces on each ſide,
The which at Touraine, in S[aint]. Katherines Church-yard,
Out of a great deale of old Iron, I chose forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dolph.
SPEECH.LINE: Then come a Gods name, I feare no woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puzel.
SPEECH.LINE: And while I liue, Ile ne're flye from a man.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Here they fight, and Ioane de Puzel ouercomes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dolph.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, ſtay thy hands, thou art an Amazon,
And fightest with the Sword of Debora.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puzel.
SPEECH.LINE: Christs Mother helpes me, else I were too weake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dolph.
SPEECH.LINE: Who e're helps thee, ‘tis thou that must help me:
Impatiently I burne with thy desire,
My heart and hands thou hast at once ſubdu’d.
Excellent Puzel, if thy name be ſo,
Let me thy ſeruant, and not Soueraigne be,
‘Tis the French Dolphin ſueth to thee thus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puzel.
SPEECH.LINE: I must not yeeld to any rights of Loue,
For my Profeſſion's ſacred from aboue:
When I haue chased all thy Fœs from hence,
Then will I thinke vpon a recompence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dolph.
SPEECH.LINE: Meane time looke gracious on thy prostrate
Thrall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reigneir.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord me thinkes is very long in talke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alans.
SPEECH.LINE: Doubtleſſe he ſhriues this woman to her ſmock,
Else ne're could he ſo long protract his ſpeech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reigneir.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall wee disturbe him, ſince hee keepes no meane?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alan.
SPEECH.LINE: He may meane more then we poor men do know,
These women are ſhrewd tempters with their tongues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reigneir.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, where are you? what deuise you on?
Shall we giue o’re Orleance, or no?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puzel.
SPEECH.LINE: Why no, I ſay: distrustfull Recreants,
Fight till the last gaspe: Ile be your guard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dolph.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhee ſayes, Ile confirme: wee'le fight it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puzel.
SPEECH.LINE: Aſſign’d am I to be the English Scourge.
This night the Siege aſſuredly Ile rayse:
Expect Saint Martins Summer, Halcyons dayes,
Since I haue entred into these Warres.
Glory is like a Circle in the Water,
Which neuer ceaseth to enlarge it ſelfe,
Till by broad ſpreading, it disperse to naught.
With Henries death, the English Circle ends,
Dispersed are the glories it included:
Now am I like that prowd insulting Ship,
Which Caesar and his fortune bare at once.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dolph.
SPEECH.LINE: Was Mahomet inspired with a Doue?
Thou with an Eagle art inspired then.
Helen, the Mother of Great Constantine,
Nor yet S[aint]. Philips daughters were like thee.
Bright Starre of Venus, falne downe on the Earth,
How may I reuerently worship thee enough?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alanson.
SPEECH.LINE: Leaue off delayes, and let vs rayse the
Siege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reigneir.
SPEECH.LINE: Woman, do what thou canst to ſaue our honors,
Driue them from Orleance, and be immortaliz’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dolph.
SPEECH.LINE: Presently wee'le try: come, let's away about it,
No Prophet will I trust, if ſhee proue false.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: I am come to ſuruey the Tower this day;
Since Henries death, I feare there is Conueyance:
Where be these Warders, that they wait not here?
Open the Gates, ‘tis Gloster that calls.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Warder.
SPEECH.LINE: Who's there, that knocks ſo imperiously?
Glost.1.Man.
It is the Noble Duke of Gloster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Warder.
SPEECH.LINE: Who ere he be, you may not be let in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Man.
SPEECH.LINE: Villaines, anſwer you ſo the Lord Protector?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Warder.
SPEECH.LINE: The Lord protect him, ſo we anſwer him,
We doe no otherwise then wee are will’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Who willed you? or whose will ſtands but mine? There's none Protector of the Realme, but I: Breake vp the Gates, Ile be your warrantize; Shall I be flowted thus by dunghill Groomes?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Glosters men rush at the Tower Gates, and Wooduile the Lieutenant ſpeakes within.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooduile.
SPEECH.LINE: What noyse is this? what Traytors haue wee here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Lieutenant, is it you whose voyce I heare?
Open the Gates, here's Gloster that would enter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooduile.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue patience Noble Duke, I may not open,
The Cardinall of Winchester forbids:
From him I haue expreſſe commandement,
That thou nor none of thine ſhall be let in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Faint-hearted Wooduile, prizest him 'fore me? Arrogant Winchester, that haughtie Prelate, Whom Henry our late Soueraigne ne're could brooke? Thou art no friend to God, or to the King: Open the Gates, or Ile ſhut thee out ſhortly. Seruingmen. Open the Gates vnto the Lord Protector, Or wee'le burst them open, if that you come not quickly.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter to the Protector at the Tower Gates, Winchester and his men in Tawney Coates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winchest.
SPEECH.LINE: How now ambitious Vmpheir, what meanes this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Piel’d Priest, doo'st thou command me to be ſhut out?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe, thou mo’t vsurping Proditor,
And not Protector of the King or Realme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand back thou manifest Conspirator,
Thou that contriued'st to murther our dead Lord,
Thou that giu'st Whores Indulgences to ſinne,
Ile canuas thee in thy broad Cardinalls Hat,
If thou proceed in this thy insolence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, ſtand thou back, I will not budge a foot:
This be Damascus, be thou cursed Cain,
To ſlay thy Brother Abel, if thou wilt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not ſlay thee, but Ile driue thee back:
Thy Scarlet Robes, as a Childs bearing Cloth,
Ile vse, to carry thee out of this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe what thou dar'st, I beard thee to thy face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: What? am I dar’d, and bearded to my face?
Draw men, for all this priuiledged place,
Blew Coats to Tawny Coats. Priest, beware your Beard,
I meane to tugge it, and to cuffe you ſoundly.
Vnder my feet I ſtampe thy Cardinalls Hat:
In ſpight of Pope, or dignities of Church,
Here by the Cheekes Ile drag thee vp and downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: Gloster, thou wilt answere this before the
Pope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Winchester Goose, I cry, a Rope, a Rope. Now beat them hence, why doe you let them ſtay? Thee Ile chase hence, thou Wolfe in Sheepes array. Out Tawney-Coates, out Scarlet Hypocrite.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Here Glosters men beat out the Cardinalls men, and enter in the hurly-burly the Maior of London, and his Officers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maior.
SPEECH.LINE: Fye Lords, that you being ſupreme Magistrates,
Thus contumeliously ſhould breake the Peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace Maior, thou know'st little of my wrongs:
Here's Beauford, that regards nor God nor King,
Hath here distrayn’d the Tower to his vse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: Here's Gloster, a Fœ to Citizens,
One that ſtill motions Warre, and neuer Peace,
O're-charging your free Purses with large Fines;
That ſeekes to ouerthrow Religion,
Because he is Protector of the Realme;
And would haue Armour here out of the Tower,
To Crowne himselfe King, and ſuppreſſe the Prince.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not anſwer thee with words, but blowes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maior.
SPEECH.LINE: Naught rests for me, in this tumultuous ſtrife, But to make open Proclamation. Come Officer, as lowd as e're thou canst, cry: All manner of men, aſſembled here in Armes this day, against Gods Peace and the Kings, wee charge and command you, in his Highneſſe Name, to repayre to your ſeuerall dwel-ling places, and not to weare, handle, or vse any Sword, Wea-pon, or Dagger hence-forward, vpon paine of death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Cardinall, Ile be no breaker of the Law:
But we ſhall meet, and breake our minds at large.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: Gloster, wee'le meet to thy cost, be ſure:
Thy heart-blood I will haue for this dayes worke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maior.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile call for Clubs, if you will not away:
This Cardinall's more haughtie then the Deuill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Maior farewell: thou doo'st but what thou may'st.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: Abhominable Gloster, guard thy Head,
For I intend to haue it ere long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maior.
SPEECH.LINE: See the Coast clear’d, and then we will depart. Good God, these Nobles ſhould ſuch ſtomacks beare, I my ſelfe fight not once in fortie yeere.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Master Gunner of Orleance, and his Boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Gunner.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirrha, thou know'st how Orleance is besieg’d,
And how the English haue the Suburbs wonne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Father I know, and oft haue ſhot at them,
How e're vnfortunate, I miſſ’d my ayme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: M.Gunner.
SPEECH.LINE: But now thou ſhalt not. Be thou rul’d by me:
Chiefe Master Gunner am I of this Towne,
Something I must doe to procure me grace:
The Princes espyals haue informed me,
How the English, in the Suburbs close entrencht,
Went through a ſecret Grate of Iron Barres,
In yonder Tower, to ouer-peere the Citie,
And thence discouer, how with mo’t aduantage
They may vex vs with Shot or with Aſſault.
To intercept this inconuenience,
A Peece of Ordnance 'gainst it I haue plac’d,
And euen these three dayes haue I watcht,
If I could ſee them. Now doe thou watch,
For I can ſtay no longer.
If thou ſpy'st any, runne and bring me word,
And thou ſhalt finde me at the Gouernors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Father, I warrant you, take you no care, Ile neuer trouble you, if I may ſpye them.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Salisbury and Talbot on the Turrets, with others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Salisb.
SPEECH.LINE: Talbot, my life, my ioy, againe return’d?
How wert thou handled, being Prisoner?
Or by what meanes got's thou to be releas’d?
Discourse I prethee on this Turrets top.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talbot.
SPEECH.LINE: The Earle of Bedford had a Prisoner,
Call’d the braue Lord Ponton de Santrayle,
For him was I exchang’d, and ransom’d.
But with a baser man of Armes by farre,
Once in contempt they would haue barter’d me:
Which I disdaining, ſcorn’d, and craued death,
Rather then I would be ſo pil’d esteem’d:
In fine, redeem’d I was as I desir’d.
But O, the trecherous Falstaffe wounds my heart,
Whom with my bare fists I would execute,
If I now had him brought into my power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Salisb.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet tell'st thou not, how thou wert enter-tain’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tal.
SPEECH.LINE: With ſcoffes and ſcornes, and contumelious taunts,
In open Market-place produc't they me,
To be a publique ſpectacle to all:
Here, ſayd they, is the Terror of the French,
The Scar-Crow that affrights our Children ſo.
Then broke I from the Officers that led me,
And with my nayles digg’d ſtones out of the ground,
To hurle at the beholders of my ſhame.
My grisly countenance made others flye,
None durst come neere, for feare of ſuddaine death.
In Iron Walls they deem’d me not ſecure:
So great feare of my Name 'mongst them were ſpread,
That they ſuppos’d I could rend Barres of Steele,
And ſpurne in pieces Posts of Adamant.
Wherefore a guard of chosen Shot I had,
That walkt about me euery Minute while:
And if I did but ſtirre out of my Bed,
Ready they were to ſhoot me to the heart.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Boy with a Linstock.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Salisb.
SPEECH.LINE: I grieue to heare what torments you endur’d,
But we will be reueng’d ſufficiently.
Now it is Supper time in Orleance:
Here, through this Grate, I count each one,
And view the Frenchmen how they fortifie:
Let vs looke in, the ſight will much delight thee:
Sir Thomas Gargraue, and Sir William Glansdale,
Let me haue your expreſſe opinions,
Where is best place to make our Batt'ry next?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gargraue.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke at the North Gate, for there ſtands
Lords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glansdale.
SPEECH.LINE: And I heere, at the Bulwarke of the
Bridge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: For ought I ſee, this Citie must be famisht,
Or with light Skirmishes enfeebled.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Here they ſhot, and Salisbury falls downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Salisb.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord haue mercy on vs, wretched ſinners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gargraue.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord haue mercy on me, wofull man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: What chance is this, that ſuddenly hath crost vs?
Speake Salisbury; at least, if thou canst, ſpeake:
How far'st thou, Mirror of all Martiall men?
One of thy Eyes, and thy Cheekes ſide ſtruck off?
Accursed Tower, accursed fatall Hand,
That hath contriu’d this wofull Tragedie.
In thirteene Battailes, Salisbury o’recame:
Henry the Fift he first trayn’d to the Warres.
Whil'st any Trumpe did ſound, or Drum ſtruck vp,
His Sword did ne're leaue ſtriking in the field.
Yet liu'st thou Salisbury? though thy ſpeech doth fayle,
One Eye thou hast to looke to Heauen for grace.
The Sunne with one Eye vieweth all the World.
Heauen be thou gracious to none aliue,
If Salisbury wants mercy at thy hands.
Beare hence his Body, I will helpe to bury it.
Sir Thomas Gargraue, hast thou any life?
Speake vnto Talbot, nay, looke vp to him.
Salisbury cheare thy Spirit with this comfort,
Thou ſhalt not dye whiles—
He beckens with his hand, and ſmiles on me:
As who ſhould ſay, When I am dead and gone,
Remember to auenge me on the French.
Plantaginet I will, and like thee,
Play on the Lute, beholding the Townes burne:
Wretched ſhall France be onely in my Name.

LINE.STAGEDIR: Here an Alarum, and it Thunders and Lightens.

SPEECH.LINE: What ſtirre is this? what tumult's in the Heauens?
Whence commeth this Alarum, and the noyse?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, my Lord, the French haue gather’d head.
The Dolphin, with one Ioane de Puzel ioyn’d,
A holy Propheteſſe, new risen vp,
Is come with a great Power, to rayse the Siege.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Here Salisbury lifteth himselfe vp, and groanes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare, heare, how dying Salisbury doth groane, It irkes his heart he cannot be reueng’d. Frenchmen, Ile be a Salisbury to you. Puzel or Puſſel, Dolphin or Dog-fish, Your hearts Ile ſtampe out with my Horses heeles, And make a Quagmire of your mingled braines. Conuey me Salisbury into his Tent, And then wee'le try what these dastard Frenchmen dare. Alarum. Exeunt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Here an Alarum againe, and Talbot pursueth the Dolphin, and driueth him: Then enter Ioane de Puzel, driuing Englishmen before her. Then enter Talbot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is my ſtrength, my valour, and my force?
Our English Troupes retyre, I cannot ſtay them,
A Woman clad in Armour chaseth them.
Here, here ſhee comes. Ile haue a bowt with thee:
Deuill, or Deuils Dam, Ile coniure thee:
Blood will I draw on thee, thou art a Witch,
And ſtraightway giue thy Soule to him thou ſeru'st.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puzel.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, ‘tis onely I that must disgrace thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauens, can you ſuffer Hell ſo to preuayle?
My brest Ile burst with ſtraining of my courage,
And from my ſhoulders crack my Armes asunder,
But I will chastise this high-minded Strumpet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puzel.
SPEECH.LINE: Talbot farwell, thy houre is not yet come, I must goe Victuall Orleance forthwith: A ſhort Alarum: then enter the Towne with Souldiers. O're-take me if thou canst, I ſcorne thy ſtrength. Goe, goe, cheare vp thy hungry-starued men, Helpe Salisbury to make his Testament, This Day is ours, as many more ſhall be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: My thoughts are whirled like a Potters Wheele,
I know not where I am, nor what I doe:
A Witch by feare, not force, like Hannibal,
Driues back our troupes, and conquers as ſhe lists:
So Bees with ſmoake, and Doues with noysome ſtench,
Are from their Hyues and Houses driuen away.
They call’d vs, for our fierceneſſe, English Dogges,
Now like to Whelpes, we crying runne away.
Hearke Countreymen, eyther renew the fight,
Or teare the Lyons out of Englands Coat;
Renounce your Soyle, giue Sheepe in Lyons ſtead:
Sheepe run not halfe ſo trecherous from the Wolfe,
Or Horse or Oxen from the Leopard,
As you flye from your oft-subdued ſlaues.
It will not be, retyre into your Trenches:
You all consented vnto Salisburies death,
For none would ſtrike a ſtroake in his reuenge.
Puzel is entred into Orleance,
In ſpight of vs, or ought that we could doe.
O would I were to dye with Salisbury,
The ſhame hereof, will make me hide my head.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter on the Walls, Puzel, Dolphin, Reigneir, Alanson, and Souldiers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puzel.
SPEECH.LINE: Aduance our wauing Colours on the Walls,
Rescu’d is Orleance from the English.
Thus Ioane de Puzel hath perform’d her word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dolph.
SPEECH.LINE: Diuinest Creature, Astrea's Daughter,
How ſhall I honour thee for this ſucceſſe?
Thy promises are like Adonis Garden,
That one day bloom’d, and fruitfull were the next.
France, triumph in thy glorious Propheteſſe,
Recouer’d is the Towne of Orleance,
More bleſſed hap did ne're befall our State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reigneir.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ring not out the Bells alowd,
Throughout the Towne?
Dolphin command the Citizens make Bonfires,
And feast and banquet in the open ſtreets,
To celebrate the ioy that God hath giuen vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alans.
SPEECH.LINE: All France will be repleat with mirth and ioy,
When they ſhall heare how we haue play’d the men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dolph.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis Ioane, not we, by whom the day is wonne:
For which, I will diuide my Crowne with her,
And all the Priests and Fryers in my Realme,
Shall in proceſſion ſing her endleſſe prayse.
A ſtatelyer Pyramis to her Ile reare,
Then Rhodophe's or Memphis euer was.
In memorie of her, when ſhe is dead,
Her Ashes, in an Vrne more precious
Then the rich-iewel’d Coffer of Darius,
Transported, ſhall be at high Festiuals
Before the Kings and Queenes of France.
No longer on Saint Dennis will we cry,
But Ioane de Puzel ſhall be France's Saint.
Come in, and let vs Banquet Royally,
After this Golden Day of Victorie.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter a Sergeant of a Band, with two Sentinels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirs, take your places, and be vigilant:
If any noyse or Souldier you perceiue
Neere to the walles, by ſome apparant ſigne
Let vs haue knowledge at the Court of Guard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sent.
SPEECH.LINE: Sergeant you ſhall. Thus are poore Seruitors
(When others ſleepe vpon their quiet beds)
Constrain’d to watch in darkneſſe, raine, and cold.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Talbot, Bedford, and Burgundy, with ſcaling Ladders: Their Drummes beating a Dead March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tal.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord Regent, and redoubted Burgundy,
By whose approach, the Regions of Artoys,
Wallon, and Picardy, are friends to vs:
This happy night, the Frenchmen are ſecure,
Hauing all day carows’d and banquetted,
Embrace we then this opportunitie,
As fitting best to quittance their deceite,
Contriu’d by Art, and balefull Sorcerie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bed.
SPEECH.LINE: Coward of France, how much he wrongs his fame,
Dispairing of his owne armes fortitude,
To ioyne with Witches, and the helpe of Hell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bur.
SPEECH.LINE: Traitors haue neuer other company.
But what’s that Puzell whom they tearme ſo pure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tal.
SPEECH.LINE: A Maid, they ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bed.
SPEECH.LINE: A Maid? And be ſo martiall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bur.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray God ſhe proue not masculine ere long:
If vnderneath the Standard of the French
She carry Armour, as ſhe hath begun.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tal.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, let them practise and conuerse with ſpirits.
God is our Fortreſſe, in whose conquering name
Let vs resolue to ſcale their flinty bulwarkes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bed.
SPEECH.LINE: Ascend braue Talbot, we will follow thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tal.
SPEECH.LINE: Not altogether: Better farre I gueſſe,
That we do make our entrance ſeuerall wayes:
That if it chance the one of vs do faile,
The other yet may rise against their force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bed.
SPEECH.LINE: Agreed; Ile to yond corner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bur.
SPEECH.LINE: And I to this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tal.
SPEECH.LINE: And heere will Talbot mount, or make his graue.
Now Salisbury, for thee and for the right
Of English Henry, ſhall this night appeare
How much in duty, I am bound to both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sent.
SPEECH.LINE: Arme, arme, the enemy doth make aſſault.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: The French leape ore the walles in their ſhirts. Enter ſeuerall wayes, Bastard, Alanson, Reignier, halfe ready, and halfe vnready.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alan.
SPEECH.LINE: How now my Lords? what all vnreadie ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnready? I and glad we ſcap’d ſo well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reig.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twas time (I trow) to wake and leaue our beds,
Hearing Alarums at our Chamber doores.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alan.
SPEECH.LINE: Of all exploits ſince first I follow’d Armes,
Nere heard I of a warlike enterprize
More venturous, or desperate then this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke this Talbot be a Fiend of Hell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reig.
SPEECH.LINE: If not of Hell, the Heauens ſure fauour him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alans.
SPEECH.LINE: Here commeth Charles, I maruell how he ſped?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, holy Ioane was his defensiue Guard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charl.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this thy cunning, thou deceitfull Dame?
Didst thou at first, to flatter vs withall,
Make vs partakers of a little gayne,
That now our loſſe might be ten times ſo much?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ioane.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore is Charles impatient with his friend?
At all times will you haue my Power alike?
Sleeping or waking, must I ſtill preuayle,
Or will you blame and lay the fault on me?
Improuident Souldiors, had your Watch been good,
This ſudden Mischiefe neuer could haue falne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charl.
SPEECH.LINE: Duke of Alanson, this was your default,
That being Captaine of the Watch to Night,
Did looke no better to that weightie Charge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alans.
SPEECH.LINE: Had all your Quarters been as ſafely kept,
As that whereof I had the gouernment,
We had not beene thus ſhamefully ſurpriz’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Mine was ſecure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reig.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo was mine, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charl.
SPEECH.LINE: And for my ſelfe, mo’t part of all this Night
Within her Quarter, and mine owne Precinct,
I was imploy’d in paſſing to and fro,
About relieuing of the Centinels.
Then how, or which way, ſhould they first breake in?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ioane.
SPEECH.LINE: Question (my Lords) no further of the case, How or which way; ‘tis ſure they found ſome place, But weakely guarded, where the breach was made: And now there rests no other ſhift but this, To gather our Souldiors, ſcatter’d and disperc't, And lay new Plat-formes to endammage them. Exeunt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Alarum. Enter a Souldier, crying, a Talbot, a Talbot: they flye, leauing their Clothes behind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sould.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile be ſo bold to take what they haue left:
The Cry of Talbot ſerues me for a Sword,
For I haue loaden me with many Spoyles,
Vsing no other Weapon but his Name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bedf.
SPEECH.LINE: The Day begins to breake, and Night is fled,
Whose pitchy Mantle ouer-vayl’d the Earth.
Here ſound Retreat, and cease our hot pursuit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Bring forth the Body of old Salisbury,
And here aduance it in the Market-Place,
The middle Centure of this cursed Towne.
Now haue I pay’d my Vow vnto his Soule:
For euery drop of blood was drawne from him,
There hath at least fiue Frenchmen dyed to night.
And that hereafter Ages may behold
What ruine happened in reuenge of him,
Within their chiefest Temple Ile erect
A Tombe, wherein his Corps ſhall be interr’d:
Vpon the which, that euery one may reade,
Shall be engrau’d the ſacke of Orleance,
The trecherous manner of his mournefull death,
And what a terror he had beene to France.
But Lords, in all our bloudy Maſſacre,
I muse we met not with the Dolphins Grace,
His new-come Champion, vertuous Ioane of Acre,
Nor any of his false Confederates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bedf.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis thought Lord Talbot, when the fight began,
Rows’d on the ſudden from their drowsie Beds,
They did amongst the troupes of armed men,
Leape o’re the Walls for refuge in the field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burg.
SPEECH.LINE: My ſelfe, as farre as I could well discerne,
For ſmoake, and duskie vapours of the night,
Am ſure I ſcar’d the Dolphin and his Trull,
When Arme in Arme they both came ſwiftly running,
Like to a payre of louing Turtle-Doues,
That could not liue asunder day or night.
After that things are ſet in order here,
Wee'le follow them with all the power we haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: All hayle, my Lords: which of this Princely trayne
Call ye the Warlike Talbot, for his Acts
So much applauded through the Realme of France?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Here is the Talbot, who would ſpeak with him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: The vertuous Lady, Counteſſe of Ouergne,
With modestie admiring thy Renowne,
By me entreats (great Lord) thou would'st vouchsafe
To visit her poore Castle where ſhe lyes,
That ſhe may boast ſhe hath beheld the man,
Whose glory fills the World with lowd report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burg.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it euen ſo? Nay, then I ſee our Warres
Will turne vnto a peacefull Comick ſport,
When Ladyes craue to be encountred with.
You may not (my Lord) despise her gentle ſuit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Ne're trust me then: for when a World of men
Could not preuayle with all their Oratorie,
Yet hath a Womans kindneſſe ouer-rul’d:
And therefore tell her, I returne great thankes,
And in ſubmiſſion will attend on her.
Will not your Honors beare me company?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bedf.
SPEECH.LINE: No, truly, ‘tis more then manners will:
And I haue heard it ſayd, Vnbidden Guests
Are often welcommest when they are gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Well then, alone (since there's no remedie)
I meane to proue this Ladyes courtesie.
Come hither Captaine, you perceiue my minde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Capt.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe my Lord, and meane accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: Porter, remember what I gaue in charge,
And when you haue done ſo, bring the Keyes to me.
Port. Madame, I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: The Plot is layd, if all things fall out right,
I ſhall as famous be by this exploit,
As Scythian Tomyris by Cyrus death.
Great is the rumour of this dreadfull Knight,
And his atchieuements of no leſſe account:
Faine would mine eyes be witneſſe with mine eares,
To giue their censure of these rare reports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Madame, according as your Ladyship desir’d,
By Meſſage crau’d, ſo is Lord Talbot come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: And he is welcome: what? is this the man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Madame, it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this the Scourge of France?
Is this the Talbot, ſo much fear’d abroad?
That with his Name the Mothers ſtill their Babes?
I ſee Report is fabulous and false.
I thought I ſhould haue ſeene ſome Hercules,
A ſecond Hector, for his grim aspect,
And large proportion of his ſtrong knit Limbes.
Alas, this is a Child, a ſilly Dwarfe:
It cannot be, this weake and writhled ſhrimpe
Should ſtrike ſuch terror to his Enemies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Madame, I haue beene bold to trouble you:
But ſince your Ladyship is not at leysure,
Ile ſort ſome other time to visit you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: What meanes he now?
Goe aske him, whither he goes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay my Lord Talbot, for my Lady craues,
To know the cause of your abrupt departure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, for that ſhee's in a wrong beleefe,
I goe to certifie her Talbot's here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: If thou be he, then art thou Prisoner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Prisoner? to whom?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: To me, blood-thirstie Lord:
And for that cause I trayn’d thee to my House.
Long time thy ſhadow hath been thrall to me,
For in my Gallery thy Picture hangs:
But now the ſubstance ſhall endure the like,
And I will chayne these Legges and Armes of thine,
That hast by Tyrannie these many yeeres
Wasted our Countrey, ſlaine our Citizens,
And ſent our Sonnes and Husbands captiuate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, ha, ha.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: Laughest thou Wretch?
Thy mirth ſhall turne to moane.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: I laugh to ſee your Ladyship ſo fond,
To thinke, that you haue ought but Talbots ſhadow,
Whereon to practise your ſeueritie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: Why? art not thou the man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: I am indeede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: Then haue I ſubstance too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, I am but ſhadow of my ſelfe:
You are deceiu’d, my ſubstance is not here;
For what you ſee, is but the ſmallest part,
And least proportion of Humanitie:
I tell you Madame, were the whole Frame here,
It is of ſuch a ſpacious loftie pitch,
Your Roofe were not ſufficient to contayn't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: This is a Riddling Merchant for the nonce,
He will be here, and yet he is not here:
How can these contrarieties agree?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: That will I ſhew you presently. Winds his Horne, Drummes ſtrike vp, a Peale of Ordenance: Enter Souldiors. How ſay you Madame? are you now perswaded, That Talbot is but ſhadow of himselfe? These are his ſubstance, ſinewes, armes, and ſtrength, With which he yoaketh your rebellious Neckes, Razeth your Cities, and ſubuerts your Townes, And in a moment makes them desolate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: Victorious Talbot, pardon my abuse,
I finde thou art no leſſe then Fame hath bruited,
And more then may be gathered by thy ſhape.
Let my presumption not prouoke thy wrath,
For I am ſorry, that with reuerence
I did not entertaine thee as thou art.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Be not dismay’d, faire Lady, nor misconster
The minde of Talbot, as you did mistake
The outward composition of his body.
What you haue done, hath not offended me:
Nor other ſatisfaction doe I craue,
But onely with your patience, that we may
Taste of your Wine, and ſee what Cates you haue,
For Souldiers ſtomacks alwayes ſerue them well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: With all my heart, and thinke me honored,
To feast ſo great a Warrior in my House.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Richard Plantagenet, Warwick, Somerset, Poole, and others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Yorke.
SPEECH.LINE: Great Lords and Gentlemen,
What meanes this ſilence?
Dare no man anſwer in a Case of Truth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Suff.
SPEECH.LINE: Within the Temple Hall we were too lowd,
The Garden here is more conuenient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: York.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſay at once, if I maintain’d the Truth:
Or else was wrangling Somerset in th’ error?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Suff.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith I haue beene a Truant in the Law,
And neuer yet could frame my will to it,
And therefore frame the Law vnto my will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: Iudge you, my Lord of Warwicke, then be-tweene vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: War.
SPEECH.LINE: Between two Hawks, which flyes the higher pitch,
Between two Dogs, which hath the deeper mouth,
Between two Blades, which beares the better temper,
Between two Horses, which doth beare him best,
Between two Girles, which hath the merryest eye,
I haue perhaps ſome ſhallow ſpirit of Iudgement:
But in these nice ſharpe Quillets of the Law,
Good faith I am no wiser then a Daw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: York.
SPEECH.LINE: Tut, tut, here is a mannerly forbearance:
The truth appeares ſo naked on my ſide,
That any purblind eye may find it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: And on my ſide it is ſo well apparrell’d,
So cleare, ſo ſhining, and ſo euident,
That it will glimmer through a blind-mans eye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: York.
SPEECH.LINE: Since you are tongue-ty’d, and ſo loth to ſpeake,
In dumbe ſignificants proclayme your thoughts:
Let him that is a true-borne Gentleman,
And ſtands vpon the honor of his birth,
If he ſuppose that I haue pleaded truth,
From off this Bryer pluck a white Rose with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: Let him that is no Coward, nor no Flatterer,
But dare maintaine the partie of the truth,
Pluck a red Rose from off this Thorne with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: War.
SPEECH.LINE: I loue no Colours: and without all colour
Of base insinuating flatterie,
I pluck this white Rose with Plantagenet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Suff.
SPEECH.LINE: I pluck this red Rose, with young Somerset,
And ſay withall, I thinke he held the right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vernon.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay Lords and Gentlemen, and pluck no more
Till you conclude, that he vpon whose ſide
The fewest Roses are cropt from the Tree,
Shall yeeld the other in the right opinion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Master Vernon, it is well obiected:
If I haue fewest, I ſubscribe in ſilence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: York.
SPEECH.LINE: And I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vernon.
SPEECH.LINE: Then for the truth, and plainneſſe of the Case,
I pluck this pale and Maiden Bloſſome here,
Giuing my Verdict on the white Rose ſide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: Prick not your finger as you pluck it off,
Least bleeding, you doe paint the white Rose red,
And fall on my ſide ſo against your will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vernon.
SPEECH.LINE: If I, my Lord, for my opinion bleed,
Opinion ſhall be Surgeon to my hurt,
And keepe me on the ſide where ſtill I am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well, come on, who else?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lawyer.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnleſſe my Studie and my Bookes be false,
The argument you held, was wrong in you;
In ſigne whereof, I pluck a white Rose too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Yorke.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Somerset, where is your argument?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: Here in my Scabbard, meditating, that
Shall dye your white Rose in a bloody red.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: York.
SPEECH.LINE: Meane time your cheeks do counterfeit our Roses:
For pale they looke with feare, as witneſſing
The truth on our ſide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: No Plantagenet:
Tis not for feare, but anger, that thy cheekes
Blush for pure ſhame, to counterfeit our Roses,
And yet thy tongue will not confeſſe thy error.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Yorke.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath not thy Rose a Canker, Somerset?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath not thy Rose a Thorne, Plantagenet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Yorke.
SPEECH.LINE: I, ſharpe and piercing to maintaine his truth,
Whiles thy consuming Canker eates his falsehood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, Ile find friends to weare my bleeding Roses,
That ſhall maintaine what I haue ſaid is true,
Where false Plantagenet dare not be ſeene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Yorke.
SPEECH.LINE: Now by this Maiden Bloſſome in my hand,
I ſcorne thee and thy fashion, peeuish Boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Suff.
SPEECH.LINE: Turne not thy ſcornes this way, Plantagenet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Yorke.
SPEECH.LINE: Prowd Poole, I will, and ſcorne both him and thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Suff.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile turne my part thereof into thy throat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, away, good William de la Poole,
We grace the Yeoman, by conuersing with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Warw.
SPEECH.LINE: Now by Gods will thou wrong'st him, Somerset:
His Grandfather was Lyonel Duke of Clarence,
Third Sonne to the third Edward King of England:
Spring Crestleſſe Yeomen from ſo deepe a Root?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Yorke.
SPEECH.LINE: He beares him on the place's Priuiledge,
Or durst not for his crauen heart ſay thus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: By him that made me, Ile maintaine my words
On any Plot of Ground in Christendome.
Was not thy Father, Richard, Earle of Cambridge,
For Treason executed in our late Kings dayes?
And by his Treason, ſtand'st not thou attainted,
Corrupted, and exempt from ancient Gentry?
His Trespas yet liues guiltie in thy blood,
And till thou be restor’d, thou art a Yeoman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Yorke.
SPEECH.LINE: My Father was attached, not attainted,
Condemn’d to dye for Treason, but no Traytor;
And that Ile proue on better men then Somerset,
Were growing time once ripened to my will.
For your partaker Poole, and you your ſelfe,
Ile note you in my Booke of Memorie,
To ſcourge you for this apprehension:
Looke to it well, and ſay you are well warn’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: Ah, thou ſhalt finde vs ready for thee ſtill:
And know vs by these Colours for thy Fœs,
For these, my friends in ſpight of thee ſhall weare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Yorke.
SPEECH.LINE: And by my Soule, this pale and angry Rose,
As Cognizance of my blood-drinking hate,
Will I for euer, and my Faction weare,
Vntill it wither with me to my Graue,
Or flourish to the height of my Degree.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Suff.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe forward, and be choak’d with thy ambition:
And ſo farwell, vntill I meet thee next.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue with thee Poole: Farwell ambitious Ri-chard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Yorke.
SPEECH.LINE: How I am brau’d, and must perforce endure it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Warw.
SPEECH.LINE: This blot that they obiect against your House,
Shall be whipt out in the next Parliament,
Call’d for the Truce of Winchester and Gloucester:
And if thou be not then created Yorke,
I will not liue to be accounted Warwicke.
Meane time, in ſignall of my loue to thee,
Against prowd Somerset, and William Poole,
Will I vpon thy partie weare this Rose.
And here I prophecie: this brawle to day,
Growne to this faction in the Temple Garden,
Shall ſend betweene the Red-Rose and the White,
A thousand Soules to Death and deadly Night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Yorke.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Master Vernon, I am bound to you,
That you on my behalfe would pluck a Flower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ver.
SPEECH.LINE: In your behalfe ſtill will I weare the ſame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lawyer.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo will I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Yorke.
SPEECH.LINE: Thankes gentle. Come, let vs foure to Dinner: I dare ſay, This Quarrell will drinke Blood another day.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Mortimer, brought in a Chayre, and Iaylors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mort.
SPEECH.LINE: Kind Keepers of my weake decaying Age,
Let dying Mortimer here rest himselfe.
Euen like a man new haled from the Wrack,
So fare my Limbes with long Imprisonment:
And these gray Locks, the Pursuiuants of death,
Nestor-like aged, in an Age of Care,
Argue the end of Edmund Mortimer.
These Eyes like Lampes, whose wasting Oyle is ſpent,
Waxe dimme, as drawing to their Exigent.
Weake Shoulders, ouer-borne with burthening Griefe,
And pyth-leſſe Armes, like to a withered Vine,
That droupes his ſappe-leſſe Branches to the ground.
Yet are these Feet, whose ſtrength-leſſe ſtay is numme,
(Vnable to ſupport this Lumpe of Clay)
Swift-winged with desire to get a Graue,
As witting I no other comfort haue.
But tell me, Keeper, will my Nephew come?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeper.
SPEECH.LINE: Richard Plantagenet, my Lord, will come:
We ſent vnto the Temple, vnto his Chamber,
And anſwer was return’d, that he will come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mort.
SPEECH.LINE: Enough: my Soule ſhall then be ſatisfied.
Poore Gentleman, his wrong doth equall mine.
Since Henry Monmouth first began to reigne,
Before whose Glory I was great in Armes,
This loathsome ſequestration haue I had;
And euen ſince then, hath Richard beene obscur’d,
Depriu’d of Honor and Inheritance.
But now, the Arbitrator of Despaires,
Iust Death, kinde Vmpire of mens miseries,
With ſweet enlargement doth dismiſſe me hence:
I would his troubles likewise were expir’d,
That ſo he might recouer what was lost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeper.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, your louing Nephew now is come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mor.
SPEECH.LINE: Richard Plantagenet, my friend, is he come?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rich.
SPEECH.LINE: I, Noble Vnckle, thus ignobly vs’d,
Your Nephew, late despised Richard, comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mort.
SPEECH.LINE: Direct mine Armes, I may embrace his Neck,
And in his Bosome ſpend my latter gaspe.
Oh tell me when my Lippes doe touch his Cheekes,
That I may kindly giue one fainting Kiſſe.
And now declare ſweet Stem from Yorkes great Stock,
Why didst thou ſay of late thou wert despis’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rich.
SPEECH.LINE: First, leane thine aged Back against mine Arme,
And in that ease, Ile tell thee my Disease.
This day in argument vpon a Case,
Some words there grew 'twixt Somerset and me:
Among which tearmes, he vs’d his lauish tongue,
And did vpbrayd me with my Fathers death;
Which obloquie ſet barres before my tongue,
Else with the like I had requited him.
Therefore good Vnckle, for my Fathers ſake,
In honor of a true Plantagenet,
And for Alliance ſake, declare the cause
My Father, Earle of Cambridge, lost his Head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mort.
SPEECH.LINE: That cause (faire Nephew) that imprison’d me,
And hath detayn’d me all my flowring Youth,
Within a loathsome Dungeon, there to pyne,
Was cursed Instrument of his decease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rich.
SPEECH.LINE: Discouer more at large what cause that was,
For I am ignorant, and cannot gueſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mort.
SPEECH.LINE: I will, if that my fading breath permit,
And Death approach not, ere my Tale be done.
Henry the Fourth, Grandfather to this King,
Depos’d his Nephew Richard, Edwards Sonne,
The first begotten, and the lawfull Heire
Of Edward King, the Third of that Descent.
During whose Reigne, the Percies of the North,
Finding his Vsurpation mo’t vniust,
Endeuour’d my aduancement to the Throne.
The reason mou’d these Warlike Lords to this,
Was, for that (young Richard thus remou’d,
Leauing no Heire begotten of his Body)
I was the next by Birth and Parentage:
For by my Mother, I deriued am
From Lionel Duke of Clarence, third Sonne
To King Edward the Third; whereas hee,
From Iohn of Gaunt doth bring his Pedigree,
Being but fourth of that Heroick Lyne.
But marke: as in this haughtie great attempt,
They laboured, to plant the rightfull Heire,
I lost my Libertie, and they their Liues.
Long after this, when Henry the Fift
(Succeeding his Father Bullingbrooke) did reigne;
Thy Father, Earle of Cambridge, then deriu’d
From famous Edmund Langley, Duke of Yorke,
Marrying my Sister, that thy Mother was;
Againe, in pitty of my hard distreſſe,
Leuied an Army, weening to redeeme,
And haue install’d me in the Diademe:
But as the rest, ſo fell that Noble Earle,
And was beheaded. Thus the Mortimers,
In whom the Title rested, were ſupprest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rich.
SPEECH.LINE: Of which, my Lord, your Honor is the last.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mort.
SPEECH.LINE: True; and thou ſeest, that I no Iſſue haue,
And that my fainting words doe warrant death:
Thou art my Heire; the rest, I wish thee gather:
But yet be wary in thy ſtudious care.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rich.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy graue admonishments preuayle with me:
But yet me thinkes, my Fathers execution
Was nothing leſſe then bloody Tyranny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mort.
SPEECH.LINE: With ſilence, Nephew, be thou pollitick,
Strong fixed is the House of Lancaster,
And like a Mountaine, not to be remou’d.
But now thy Vnckle is remouing hence,
As Princes doe their Courts, when they are cloy’d
With long continuance in a ſetled place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rich.
SPEECH.LINE: O Vnckle, would ſome part of my young yeeres
Might but redeeme the paſſage of your Age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mort.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou do'st then wrong me, as y ſlaughterer doth,
Which giueth many Wounds, when one will kill.
Mourne not, except thou ſorrow for my good,
Onely giue order for my Funerall.
And ſo farewell, and faire be all thy hopes,
And prosperous be thy Life in Peace and Warre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rich.
SPEECH.LINE: And Peace, no Warre, befall thy parting Soule.
In Prison hast thou ſpent a Pilgrimage,
And like a Hermite ouer-past thy dayes.
Well, I will locke his Councell in my Brest,
And what I doe imagine, let that rest.
Keepers conuey him hence, and I my ſelfe
Will ſee his Buryall better then his Life.
Here dyes the duskie Torch of Mortimer,
Choakt with Ambition of the meaner ſort.
And for those Wrongs, those bitter Iniuries,
Which Somerset hath offer’d to my House,
I doubt not, but with Honor to redreſſe.
And therefore haste I to the Parliament,
Eyther to be restored to my Blood,
Or make my will th’ aduantage of my good.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter King, Exeter, Gloster, Winchester, Warwick. Somerset, Suffolk, Richard Plantagenet. Gloster offers to put vp a Bill: Winchester ſnatches it, teares it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: Com'st thou with deepe premeditated Lines?
With written Pamphlets, ſtudiously deuis’d?
Humfrey of Gloster, if thou canst accuse,
Or ought intend'st to lay vnto my charge,
Doe it without inuention, ſuddenly,
As I with ſudden, and extemporall ſpeech,
Purpose to anſwer what thou canst obiect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: Presumptuous Priest, this place co[m]mands my patie[n]ce,
Or thou ſhould'st finde thou hast dis-honor’d me.
Thinke not, although in Writing I preferr’d
The manner of thy vile outragious Crymes,
That therefore I haue forg’d, or am not able
Verbatim to rehearse the Methode of my Penne.
No Prelate, ſuch is thy audacious wickedneſſe,
Thy lewd, pestiferous, and diſſentious prancks,
As very Infants prattle of thy pride.
Thou art a mo’t pernitious Vsurer,
Froward by nature, Enemie to Peace,
Lasciuious, wanton, more then well beseemes
A man of thy Profeſſion, and Degree.
And for thy Trecherie, what’s more manifest?
In that thou layd'st a Trap to take my Life,
As well at London Bridge, as at the Tower.
Beside, I feare me, if thy thoughts were ſifted,
The King, thy Soueraigne, is not quite exempt
From enuious mallice of thy ſwelling heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: Gloster, I doe defie thee. Lords vouchsafe
To giue me hearing what I ſhall reply.
If I were couetous, ambitious, or peruerse,
As he will haue me: how am I ſo poore?
Or how haps it, I ſeeke not to aduance
Or rayse my ſelfe? but keepe my wonted Calling.
And for Diſſention, who preferreth Peace
More then I doe? except I be prouok’d.
No, my good Lords, it is not that offends,
It is not that, that hath incens’d the Duke:
It is because no one ſhould ſway but hee,
No one, but hee, ſhould be about the King;
And that engenders Thunder in his breast,
And makes him rore these Accusations forth.
But he ſhall know I am as good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: As good?
Thou Bastard of my Grandfather.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: I, Lordly Sir: for what are you, I pray,
But one imperious in anothers Throne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Am I not Protector, ſawcie Priest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: And am not I a Prelate of the Church?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, as an Out-law in a Castle keepes,
And vseth it, to patronage his Theft.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnreuerent Glocester.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art reuerent,
Touching thy Spirituall Function, not thy Life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: Rome ſhall remedie this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Warw.
SPEECH.LINE: Roame thither then.
My Lord, it were your dutie to forbeare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: I, ſee the Bishop be not ouer-borne:
Me thinkes my Lord ſhould be Religious,
And know the Office that belongs to ſuch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Warw.
SPEECH.LINE: Me thinkes his Lordship ſhould be humbler,
It fitteth not a Prelate ſo to plead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, when his holy State is toucht ſo neere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Warw.
SPEECH.LINE: State holy, or vnhallow’d, what of that?
Is not his Grace Protector to the King?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rich.
SPEECH.LINE: Plantagenet I ſee must hold his tongue,
Least it be ſaid, Speake Sirrha when you ſhould:
Must your bold Verdict enter talke with Lords?
Else would I haue a fling at Winchester.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnckles of Gloster, and of Winchester,
The ſpeciall Watch-men of our English Weale,
I would preuayle, if Prayers might preuayle,
To ioyne your hearts in loue and amitie.
Oh, what a Scandall is it to our Crowne,
That two ſuch Noble Peeres as ye ſhould iarre?
Beleeue me, Lords, my tender yeeres can tell,
Ciuill diſſention is a viperous Worme,
That gnawes the Bowels of the Common-wealth.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: A noyse within, Downe with the Tawny-Coats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: What tumult's this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Warw.
SPEECH.LINE: An Vprore, I dare warrant,
Begun through malice of the Bishops men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maior.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh my good Lords, and vertuous Henry,
Pitty the Citie of London, pitty vs:
The Bishop, and the Duke of Glosters men,
Forbidden late to carry any Weapon,
Haue fill’d their Pockets full of peeble ſtones;
And banding themselues in contrary parts,
Doe pelt ſo fast at one anothers Pate,
That many haue their giddy braynes knockt out:
Our Windowes are broke downe in euery Street,
And we, for feare, compell’d to ſhut our Shops.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter in ſkirmish with bloody Pates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: We charge you, on allegeance to our ſelfe,
To hold your ſlaughtring hands, and keepe the Peace:
Pray' Vnckle Gloster mittigate this ſtrife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Seruing.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, if we be forbidden Stones, wee'le fall to it with our Teeth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Seruing.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe what ye dare, we are as resolute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: You of my household, leaue this peeuish broyle,
And ſet this vnaccustom’d fight aside.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Seru.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, we know your Grace to be a man
Iust, and vpright; and for your Royall Birth,
Inferior to none, but to his Maiestie:
And ere that we will ſuffer ſuch a Prince,
So kinde a Father of the Common-weale,
To be disgraced by an Inke-horne Mate,
Wee and our Wiues and Children all will fight,
And haue our bodyes ſlaughtred by thy fœs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Seru.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and the very parings of our Nayles
Shall pitch a Field when we are dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, ſtay, I ſay:
And if you loue me, as you ſay you doe,
Let me perswade you to forbeare a while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, how this discord doth afflict my Soule.
Can you, my Lord of Winchester, behold
My ſighes and teares, and will not once relent?
Who ſhould be pittifull, if you be not?
Or who ſhould ſtudy to preferre a Peace,
If holy Church-men take delight in broyles?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Warw.
SPEECH.LINE: Yeeld my Lord Protector, yeeld Winchester,
Except you meane with obstinate repulse
To ſlay your Soueraigne, and destroy the Realme.
You ſee what Mischiefe, and what Murther too,
Hath beene enacted through your enmitie:
Then be at peace, except ye thirst for blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſhall ſubmit, or I will neuer yeeld.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Compaſſion on the King commands me ſtoupe,
Or I would ſee his heart out, ere the Priest
Should euer get that priuiledge of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Warw.
SPEECH.LINE: Behold my Lord of Winchester, the Duke
Hath banisht moodie discontented fury,
As by his ſmoothed Browes it doth appeare:
Why looke you ſtill ſo ſterne, and tragicall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Here Winchester, I offer thee my Hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie Vnckle Beauford, I haue heard you preach,
That Mallice was a great and grieuous ſinne:
And will not you maintaine the thing you teach?
But proue a chiefe offendor in the ſame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Warw.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet King: the Bishop hath a kindly gyrd:
For ſhame my Lord of Winchester relent;
What, ſhall a Child instruct you what to doe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, Duke of Gloster, I will yeeld to thee
Loue for thy Loue, and Hand for Hand I giue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but I feare me with a hollow Heart.
See here my Friends and louing Countreymen,
This token ſerueth for a Flagge of Truce,
Betwixt our ſelues, and all our followers:
So helpe me God, as I diſſemble not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: So helpe me God, as I intend it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh louing Vnckle, kinde Duke of Gloster,
How ioyfull am I made by this Contract.
Away my Masters, trouble vs no more,
But ioyne in friendship, as your Lords haue done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Seru.
SPEECH.LINE: Content, Ile to the Surgeons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Seru.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo will I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 3.Seru.
SPEECH.LINE: And I will ſee what Physick the Tauerne af-fords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Warw.
SPEECH.LINE: Accept this Scrowle, mo’t gracious Soueraigne,
Which in the Right of Richard Plantagenet,
We doe exhibite to your Maiestie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: Well vrg’d, my Lord of Warwick: for ſweet Prince,
And if your Grace marke euery circumstance,
You haue great reason to doe Richard right,
Especially for those occasions
At Eltam Place I told your Maiestie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: And those occasions, Vnckle, were of force:
Therefore my louing Lords, our pleasure is,
That Richard be restored to his Blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Warw.
SPEECH.LINE: Let Richard be restored to his Blood,
So ſhall his Fathers wrongs be recompenc't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winch.
SPEECH.LINE: As will the rest, ſo willeth Winchester.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: If Richard will be true, not that all alone,
But all the whole Inheritance I giue,
That doth belong vnto the House of Yorke,
From whence you ſpring, by Lineall Descent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rich.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy humble ſeruant vowes obedience,
And humble ſeruice, till the point of death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Stoope then, and ſet your Knee against my Foot,
And in reguerdon of that dutie done,
I gyrt thee with the valiant Sword of Yorke:
Rise Richard, like a true Plantagenet,
And rise created Princely Duke of Yorke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rich.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo thriue Richard, as thy fœs may fall,
And as my dutie ſprings, ſo perish they,
That grudge one thought against your Maiesty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome high Prince, the mighty Duke of Yorke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Som.
SPEECH.LINE: Perish base Prince, ignoble Duke of Yorke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Now will it best auaile your Maiestie,
To croſſe the Seas, and to be Crown’d in France:
The presence of a King engenders loue
Amongst his Subiects, and his loyall Friends,
As it dis-animates his Enemies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: When Gloster ſayes the word, King Henry goes,
For friendly counsaile cuts off many Fœs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Ships alreadie are in readineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Exet.
SPEECH.LINE: I, we may march in England, or in France,
Not ſeeing what is likely to ensue:
This late diſſention growne betwixt the Peeres,
Burnes vnder fained ashes of forg’d loue,
And will at last breake out into a flame,
As festred members rot but by degree,
Till bones and flesh and ſinewes fall away,
So will this base and enuious discord breed.
And now I feare that fatall Prophecie,
Which in the time of Henry, nam’d the Fift,
Was in the mouth of euery ſucking Babe,
That Henry borne at Monmouth ſhould winne all,
And Henry borne at Windsor, loose all:
Which is ſo plaine, that Exeter doth wish,
His dayes may finish, ere that hapleſſe time.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Pucell disguis’d, with foure Souldiors with Sacks vpon their backs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pucell.
SPEECH.LINE: These are the Citie Gates, the Gates of Roan,
Through which our Pollicy must make a breach.
Take heed, be wary how you place your words,
Talke like the vulgar ſort of Market men,
That come to gather Money for their Corne.
If we haue entrance, as I hope we ſhall,
And that we finde the ſlouthfull Watch but weake,
Ile by a ſigne giue notice to our friends,
That Charles the Dolphin may encounter them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Souldier.
SPEECH.LINE: Our Sacks ſhall be a meane to ſack the City,
And we be Lords and Rulers ouer Roan,
Therefore wee'le knock.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.
SPEECH.LINE: Che la.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pucell.
SPEECH.LINE: Peasauns la pouure gens de Fraunce,
Poore Market folkes that come to ſell their Corne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watch.
SPEECH.LINE: Enter, goe in, the Market Bell is rung.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pucell.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Roan, Ile ſhake thy Bulwarkes to the ground.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles.
SPEECH.LINE: Saint Dennis bleſſe this happy Stratageme,
And once againe wee'le ſleepe ſecure in Roan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bastard.
SPEECH.LINE: Here entred Pucell, and her Practisants:
Now ſhe is there, how will ſhe ſpecifie?
Here is the best and ſafest paſſage in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reig.
SPEECH.LINE: By thrusting out a Torch from yonder Tower,
Which once discern’d, ſhewes that her meaning is,
No way to that (for weakneſſe) which ſhe entred.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Pucell on the top, thrusting out a Torch burning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pucell.
SPEECH.LINE: Behold, this is the happy Wedding Torch,
That ioyneth Roan vnto her Countreymen,
But burning fatall to the Talbonites.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bastard.
SPEECH.LINE: See Noble Charles the Beacon of our friend,
The burning Torch in yonder Turret ſtands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles.
SPEECH.LINE: Now ſhine it like a Commet of Reuenge,
A Prophet to the fall of all our Fœs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reig.
SPEECH.LINE: Deferre no time, delayes haue dangerous ends,
Enter and cry, the Dolphin, presently,
And then doe execution on the Watch. Alarum.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: An Alarum. Talbot in an Excursion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: France, thou ſhalt rue this Treason with thy teares, If Talbot but ſuruiue thy Trecherie. Pucell that Witch, that damned Sorcereſſe, Hath wrought this Hellish Mischiefe vnawares, That hardly we escap't the Pride of France.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: An Alarum: Excursions. Bedford brought in ſicke in a Chayre.
Enter Talbot and Burgonie without: within, Pucell, Charles, Bastard, and Reigneir on the Walls.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pucell.
SPEECH.LINE: God morrow Gallants, want ye Corn for Bread?
I thinke the Duke of Burgonie will fast,
Before hee'le buy againe at ſuch a rate.
'Twas full of Darnell: doe you like the taste?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burg.
SPEECH.LINE: Scoffe on vile Fiend, and ſhameleſſe Curtizan,
I trust ere long to choake thee with thine owne,
And make thee curse the Haruest of that Corne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Grace may ſtarue (perhaps) before that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bedf.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh let no words, but deedes, reuenge this Trea-son.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pucell.
SPEECH.LINE: What will you doe, good gray-beard?
Breake a Launce, and runne a-Tilt at Death,
Within a Chayre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Foule Fiend of France, and Hag of all despight,
Incompaſſ’d with thy lustfull Paramours,
Becomes it thee to taunt his valiant Age,
And twit with Cowardise a man halfe dead?
Damsell, Ile haue a bowt with you againe,
Or else let Talbot perish with this ſhame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pucell.
SPEECH.LINE: Are ye ſo hot, Sir: yet Pucell hold thy peace,
If Talbot doe but Thunder, Raine will follow.
God ſpeed the Parliament: who ſhall be the Speaker?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Dare yee come forth, and meet vs in the field?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pucell.
SPEECH.LINE: Belike your Lordship takes vs then for fooles,
To try if that our owne be ours, or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſpeake not to that rayling Hecate,
But vnto thee Alanson, and the rest.
Will ye, like Souldiors, come and fight it out?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alans.
SPEECH.LINE: Seignior no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Seignior hang: base Muleters of France,
Like Pesant foot-Boyes doe they keepe the Walls,
And dare not take vp Armes, like Gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pucell.
SPEECH.LINE: Away Captaines, let's get vs from the Walls,
For Talbot meanes no goodneſſe by his Lookes.
God b'uy my Lord, we came but to tell you
That wee are here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: And there will we be too, ere it be long,
Or else reproach be Talbots greatest fame.
Vow Burgonie, by honor of thy House,
Prickt on by publike Wrongs ſustain’d in France,
Either to get the Towne againe, or dye.
And I, as ſure as English Henry liues,
And as his Father here was Conqueror;
As ſure as in this late betrayed Towne,
Great Cordelions Heart was buryed;
So ſure I ſweare, to get the Towne, or dye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burg.
SPEECH.LINE: My Vowes are equall partners with thy
Vowes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: But ere we goe, regard this dying Prince,
The valiant Duke of Bedford: Come my Lord,
We will bestow you in ſome better place,
Fitter for ſickneſſe, and for crasie age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bedf.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord Talbot, doe not ſo dishonour me:
Here will I ſit, before the Walls of Roan,
And will be partner of your weale or wœ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burg.
SPEECH.LINE: Couragious Bedford, let vs now perswade you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bedf.
SPEECH.LINE: Not to be gone from hence: for once I read,
That ſtout Pendragon, in his Litter ſick,
Came to the field, and vanquished his fœs.
Me thinkes I ſhould reuiue the Souldiors hearts,
Because I euer found them as my ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Vndaunted ſpirit in a dying breast,
Then be it ſo: Heauens keepe old Bedford ſafe.
And now no more adœ, braue Burgonie,
But gather we our Forces out of hand,
And ſet vpon our boasting Enemie.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: An Alarum: Excursions. Enter Sir Iohn Falstaffe, and a Captaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Capt.
SPEECH.LINE: Whither away Sir Iohn Falstaffe, in ſuch haste?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: Whither away? to ſaue my ſelfe by flight,
We are like to haue the ouerthrow againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Capt.
SPEECH.LINE: What? will you flye, and leaue Lord Talbot?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falst.
SPEECH.LINE: I, all the Talbots in the World, to ſaue my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Capt.
SPEECH.LINE: Cowardly Knight, ill fortune follow thee.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Retreat. Excursions. Pucell, Alanson, and Charles flye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bedf.
SPEECH.LINE: Now quiet Soule, depart when Heauen please, For I haue ſeene our Enemies ouerthrow. What is the trust or ſtrength of foolish man? They that of late were daring with their ſcoffes, Are glad and faine by flight to ſaue themselues. Bedford dyes, and is carryed in by two in his Chaire.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: An Alarum. Enter Talbot, Burgonie, and the rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Lost, and recouered in a day againe,
This is a double Honor, Burgonie:
Yet Heauens haue glory for this Victorie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burg.
SPEECH.LINE: Warlike and Martiall Talbot, Burgonie
Inshrines thee in his heart, and there erects
Thy noble Deeds, as Valors Monuments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: Thanks gentle Duke: but where is Pucel now?
I thinke her old Familiar is asleepe.
Now where's the Bastards braues, and Charles his glikes?
What all amort? Roan hangs her head for griefe,
That ſuch a valiant Company are fled.
Now will we take ſome order in the Towne,
Placing therein ſome expert Officers,
And then depart to Paris, to the King,
For there young Henry with his Nobles lye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burg.
SPEECH.LINE: What wills Lord Talbot, pleaseth Burgonie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Talb.
SPEECH.LINE: But yet before we goe, let's not forget
The Noble Duke of Bedford, late deceas’d,
But ſee his Exequies fulfill’d in Roan.
A brauer Souldier neuer couched Launce,
A gentler Heart did neuer ſway in Court.
But Kings and mightiest Potentates must die,
For that’s the end of humane miserie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pucell.
SPEECH.LINE: Dismay not (Princes) at this accident,
Nor grieue that Roan is ſo recouered:
Care is no cure, but rather corrosiue,
For things that are not to be remedy’d.
Let frantike Talbot triumph for a while,
And like a Peacock ſweepe along his tayle,
Wee'le pull his Plumes, and take away his Trayne,
If Dolphin and the rest will be but rul’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles.
SPEECH.LINE: We haue been guided by thee hitherto,
And of thy Cunning had no diffidence,
One ſudden Foyle ſhall neuer breed distrust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bastard.
SPEECH.LINE: Search out thy wit for ſecret pollicies,
And we will make thee famous through the World.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alans.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'le ſet thy Statue in ſome holy place,
And haue thee reuerenc't like a bleſſed Saint.
Employ thee then, ſweet Virgin, for our good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pucell.
SPEECH.LINE: Then thus it must be, this doth Ioane deuise:
By faire perswasions, mixt with ſugred words,
We will entice the Duke of Burgonie
To leaue the Talbot, and to follow vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles.
SPEECH.LINE: I marry Sweeting, if we could doe that,
France were no place for Henryes Warriors,
Nor ſhould that Nation boast it ſo with vs,
But be extirped from our Prouinces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alans.
SPEECH.LINE: For euer ſhould they be expuls’d from France,
And not haue Title of an Earledome here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pucell.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Honors ſhall perceiue how I will worke,
To bring this matter to the wished end.
Hearke, by the ſound of Drumme you may perceiue
Their Powers are marching vnto Paris-ward.
There goes the Talbot with his Colours ſpred,
And all the Troupes of English after him.
Now in the Rereward comes the Duke and his:
Fortune in fauor makes him lagge behinde.
Summon a Parley, we will talke with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles.
SPEECH.LINE: A Parley with the Duke of Burgonie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burg.
SPEECH.LINE: Who craues a Parley with the Burgonie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pucell.
SPEECH.LINE: The Princely Charles of France, thy Countrey-man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burg.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſay'st thou Charles? for I am marching hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake Pucell, and enchaunt him with thy words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pucell.
